page.title: 01General Review
page.content: This block includes the large village of Chesterton together with farmland and hamlets to the west of it. The settlements in this area owe their existance to the coal mined here on part of the North Staffordshire coal field and still retain some of their original character, although the large centre of population, Chesterton, is now much influenced by its proximity to the town of Newcastle-under-Lyme whose borough council has built new large housing estates here. The farm- land, situated at the edge of the Cheshire plain, is predominantly pasture. Some woodland remains, a reminder of the Lyme forest which used to cover the area. The landscape bears the scars of old extractive industry and is soon to have new ones added from open-cast mining.
